title: Tutorial for MotrpacRatTraining6moData R package
text: Details experimental design can found supplementary methods bioRxiv preprint (TODO: add link). Briefly, 6-month-old young adult rats subjected progressive endurance exercise training 1, 2, 4, 8 weeks, tissues collected 48 hours last training bout. Sex-matched sedentary, untrained rats used controls. Whole blood, plasma, 18 solid tissues analyzed using genomics, proteomics, metabolomics, protein immunoassay technologies, assays performed subset tissues. Depending assay, 3 5 replicates per sex per time point analyzed.

title: Tutorial for MotrpacRatTraining6moData R package
text: show combine normalized RNA-seq data gastrocnemius (leg skeletal muscle) phenotypic data perform principal component analysis (PCA). also take advantage training group colors.
code: # Load data  # While this is not necessary, we want to make it clear what objects are available in the package. # Note you can use data directly without loading with `data()`, e.g., `head(PHENO)` data(PHENO) # phenotypic data data(TRNSCRPT_SKMGN_NORM_DATA) # normalized gastrocnemius RNA-seq data data(GROUP_COLORS) # hex colors for training groups   # The first four columns in the sample-level data specify row meta-data; next columns are samples # Note the "feature" column is only non-NA for training-regulated features at 5% FDR TRNSCRPT_SKMGN_NORM_DATA[1:3,1:6] #>   feature         feature_ID tissue    assay 90560015512 90581015512 #> 1    <NA> ENSRNOG00000000008 SKM-GN TRNSCRPT     0.04044    -0.09760 #> 2    <NA> ENSRNOG00000000012 SKM-GN TRNSCRPT     2.61487     2.78841 #> 3    <NA> ENSRNOG00000000021 SKM-GN TRNSCRPT     2.17049     1.70091 sample_ids = colnames(TRNSCRPT_SKMGN_NORM_DATA)[-c(1:4)]  # Perform PCA skmgn_pca = stats::prcomp(t(TRNSCRPT_SKMGN_NORM_DATA[,sample_ids]))  # Make a data frame with some phenotypic data and the first 3 PCs df = data.frame(   group = PHENO[sample_ids,"group"],   sex = PHENO[sample_ids,"sex"],   skmgn_pca$x[,1:3] # take the first principal components )  # Plot the first two PCs ggplot(df, aes(x=PC1, y=PC2, colour=group, shape=sex)) +    geom_point(size=3) # Use GROUP_COLORS and make it prettier  ggplot(df, aes(x=PC1, y=PC2, fill=group, shape=sex)) +    geom_point(size=3, colour="black") +   scale_fill_manual(values=GROUP_COLORS) +   scale_shape_manual(values=c(male=21, female=24)) +   theme_bw() +   guides(fill=guide_legend(override.aes = list(shape=21))) +   labs(title="PCA of Gastrocnemius RNA-seq data") +   theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust=0.5))

title: Tutorial for MotrpacRatTraining6moData R package
text: First, load normalized data ome. default, column names sample-level data vial labels, sample-specific identifiers. Different samples sample animal processed different assays. Therefore, order map samples animal across assays, need map sample IDs participant IDs (PIDs) biospecimen IDs (BIDs). , map vial labels (sample IDs) BIDs BIDs conveniently substring vial labels. PHENO can also used map vial labels (viallabel), PID (pid), BID (bid). Now used FEATURE_TO_GENE map map RNA-seq proteomics feature IDs gene symbols. FEATURE_TO_GENE large (>4M rows), start subsetting features current analysis. Use sample--BID mapping feature--gene mapping subset RNA-seq proteomics data overlapping BIDs genes. cases multiple feature IDs map gene, take average value per BID.
code: rnaseq_d = TRNSCRPT_HEART_NORM_DATA prot_d = PROT_HEART_NORM_DATA ## Match sample ids #' A helper function for getting a named vector that maps biospecimen ids to sample ids #' The biospecimen id of each sample is the substring of the sample id. map_sample_to_bid = function(x){   names(x) = substring(first=1, last=5, x)   x } rnaseq_bid = map_sample_to_bid(colnames(rnaseq_d)[-c(1:4)]) prot_bid = map_sample_to_bid(colnames(prot_d)[-c(1:4)]) shared_bids = intersect(names(rnaseq_bid),names(prot_bid)) dim(FEATURE_TO_GENE) #> [1] 4044034       9 f2g = FEATURE_TO_GENE[   FEATURE_TO_GENE$feature_ID %in% union(rnaseq_d$feature_ID,prot_d$feature_ID), ] dim(f2g) #> [1] 24591     9 # Get new RNA-seq and proteomics data frames # here we compute the gene-wise average profiles, while limiting the # data to the shared biospecimen ids rnaseq_x = merge(rnaseq_d, f2g[,c("feature_ID","gene_symbol")], by="feature_ID") rnaseq_x = stats::aggregate(   rnaseq_x[,rnaseq_bid[shared_bids]], # get the shared samples   by = list(rnaseq_x$gene_symbol), mean, na.rm=T)  # Same for proteomics prot_x = merge(prot_d,f2g[,c("feature_ID","gene_symbol")],by="feature_ID") prot_x = stats::aggregate(   prot_x[,prot_bid[shared_bids]], # get the shared samples   by = list(prot_x$gene_symbol),mean,na.rm=T)  # remove proteomics genes with missing values prot_x = prot_x[!apply(is.na(prot_x),1,any),]  # Subset the data to the shared genes rownames(rnaseq_x) = rnaseq_x[,1] rnaseq_x = rnaseq_x[,-1] rownames(prot_x) = prot_x[,1] prot_x = prot_x[,-1] shared_genes = intersect(rownames(rnaseq_x),rownames(prot_x)) prot_x = prot_x[shared_genes,] rnaseq_x = rnaseq_x[shared_genes,]

title: Tutorial for MotrpacRatTraining6moData R package
text: Now can perform simple differential analysis males trained 8 weeks sedentary control males identify genes regulated training. separately RNA-seq proteomics data. use t-tests simplicity, appropriate way compute differential abundance use tools like limma DESeq2. Fortunately, robust results also available package!
code: # Perform simple t-tests ttest_wrapper <- function(x, groups, group1, group2){   x1 = x[groups==group1]   x2 = x[groups==group2]   tres = t.test(x1,x2)   return(c(     "logFC" = unname(tres$estimate[1]-tres$estimate[2]),     "tscore" = unname(tres$statistic),     "p_value" = tres$p.value   )) }  # Compute t-tests for week 8 in males training_groups = paste(   PHENO[colnames(rnaseq_x),"sex"],   PHENO[colnames(rnaseq_x),"group"], sep="," ) male_8w_rnaseq_ttests = apply(rnaseq_x,                               1,                               ttest_wrapper,                               groups=training_groups,                               group1="male,8w",                               group2="male,control") male_8w_prot_ttests = apply(prot_x,                             1,                             ttest_wrapper,                             groups=training_groups,                             group1="male,8w",                             group2="male,control")  # As we observed in the paper, the differential analysis results are mildly correlated: cor(male_8w_rnaseq_ttests["tscore",], male_8w_prot_ttests["tscore",]) #> [1] 0.1920838

title: Tutorial for MotrpacRatTraining6moData R package
text: Now compare results simple t-test differential analysis results DESeq2 (RNA-seq) limma (proteomics).
code: rnaseq_DA = TRNSCRPT_HEART_DA prot_DA = PROT_HEART_DA  # subset the results to 8w, males rnaseq_DA = rnaseq_DA[rnaseq_DA$sex == "male" & rnaseq_DA$comparison_group=="8w",] prot_DA = prot_DA[prot_DA$sex == "male" & prot_DA$comparison_group=="8w",]  # Add gene symbols rnaseq_DA = merge(rnaseq_DA, f2g[,c("feature_ID","gene_symbol")], by="feature_ID") prot_DA = merge(prot_DA, f2g[,c("feature_ID","gene_symbol")], by="feature_ID")  # Get the best t-test results per gene get_best_zscore = function(zs){   return(zs[abs(zs)==max(abs(zs),na.rm = T)][1]) } rnaseq_t = tapply(rnaseq_DA$zscore,                   rnaseq_DA$gene_symbol,                   get_best_zscore) prot_t = tapply(prot_DA$tscore,                 prot_DA$gene_symbol,                 get_best_zscore)  # Again, we see mild but non-zero correlation cor(rnaseq_t[shared_genes],prot_t[shared_genes]) #> [1] 0.2126466  # Here we show an almost perfect correlation between the pre-computed  # RNA-seq DESeq2 results and the simple t-tests performed above plot(rnaseq_t[shared_genes],      male_8w_rnaseq_ttests["tscore",shared_genes],      main = "Transcriptomics DA, males at week 8",      xlab = "DESeq2 t-score",ylab = "Simple t-test statistic",      pch=20,col="gray");abline(0,1,lty=2) # Same as above, but for proteomics plot(prot_t[shared_genes],male_8w_prot_ttests["tscore",shared_genes],      main = "Proteomics DA, males at week 8",      xlab = "limma t-score",ylab = "Simple t-test statistic",      pch=20,col="gray");abline(0,1,lty=2)

title: Differential analysis of ATAC-seq data — ATAC_DA
text: data frame 21 variables: feature character, unique feature identifier format 'ASSAY_ABBREV;TISSUE_ABBREV;feature_ID' training-regulated features 5% IHW FDR. redundant differential features, 'feature_ID' prepended specific platform make unique identifiers. See REPEATED_FEATURES details. assay character, assay abbreviation, one ASSAY_ABBREV assay_code character, assay code used data release. See MotrpacBicQC::assay_codes. tissue character, tissue abbreviation, one TISSUE_ABBREV tissue_code character, tissue code used data release. See MotrpacBicQC::bic_animal_tissue_code. feature_ID character, MoTrPAC feature identifier dataset character, tissue code Chemical Analysis Site generated data. Note ATAC data generated Stanford included repository. sex character, one 'male' 'female' comparison_group character, time point trained animals compared sex-matched sedentary control animals, one '1w', '2w', '4w', '8w' p_value double, unadjusted p-value difference 'comparison_group' group sex-matched sedentary control animals adj_p_value double, adjusted p-value 'p_value' column. P-values -adjusted across datasets within given assay/ome. logFC double, log fold-change numerator 'comparison_group', e.g., '1w', denominator group sex-matched sedentary control animals logFC_se double, standard error log fold-change tscore double, t statistic covariates character, comma-separated list adjustment variables NA removed_samples character, comma-separated list vial labels excluded differential analysis NA comparison_average_intensity double, average intensity among replicates 'comparison_group' comparison_average_intensity_se double, standard error 'comparison_average_intensity' reference_average_intensity double, average intensity among replicates group sex-matched sedentary control animals reference_average_intensity_se double, standard error 'reference_average_intensity' selection_fdr double, adjusted training p-value used select training-regulated analytes. P-values IHW-adjusted across datasets within given assay tissue covariate.

title: Differential analysis of ATAC-seq data — ATAC_DA
text: Unfiltered ATAC differential analysis results available via download Google Cloud Storage. example, https://storage.googleapis.com/motrpac-rat-training-6mo-extdata/ATAC_BAT_DA.rda file brown adipose tissue (BAT) results. can change name file specify tissues including: HEART, HIPPOC, KIDNEY, LIVER, LUNG, SKMGN (gastrocnemius skeletal muscle), WATSC (subcutaneous white adipose tissue). can also use MotrpacRatTraining6mo::get_rdata_from_url() download differential analysis results ATAC METHYL. details files see readme repository https://github.com/MoTrPAC/MotrpacRatTraining6mo/blob/main/README.md. training-regulated ATAC features 5% FDR, see TRAINING_REGULATED_FEATURES. Reproduce analysis MotrpacRatTraining6mo::atac_timewise_da() MotrpacRatTraining6mo::atac_training_da().

title: ATAC-seq feature annotation — ATAC_FEATURE_ANNOT
text: data frame 1209773 rows 16 variables: assay character, assay abbreviation, one ASSAY_ABBREV assay_code character, assay code used data release. See MotrpacBicQC::assay_codes. feature_ID character, MoTrPAC feature identifier chrom character, chromosome: 1-20, X, Y start double, base pair feature start end double, base bair feature end width integer, width feature base pairs chipseeker_annotation character, annotation ChIPseeker::annotatePeak() custom_annotation character, version ChIPseeker annotations many corrections. Values include: "Distal Intergenic", "Promoter (<=1kb)", "Exon", "Promoter (1-2kb)", "Downstream (<5kb)", "Upstream (<5kb)", "5' UTR", "Intron", "3' UTR", "Overlaps Gene", "Overlaps Gene" means feature non-zero overlap either start end gene otherwise asssigned annotation. distanceToTSS double, minimum distance one end feature transcription start site. relationship_to_gene double, distance closest edge feature start end closest gene, whichever closer. value 0 means non-zero overlap feature gene. negative value means feature upstream geneStart. positive value means feature downstream geneEnd. Note geneStart geneEnd strand-agnostic, .e. geneStart always less geneEnd, even gene negative strand (geneStrand == 2). ensembl_gene character, Ensembl gene ID release 96 Rattus norvegicus gene annotation geneStart integer, base pair start gene; strand-agnostic, meaning geneStart always less geneEnd geneEnd integer, base pair end gene; strand-agnostic, meaning geneStart always less geneEnd geneLength integer, length gene base pairs geneStrand integer, 1 (forward strand) 2 (reverse strand)

title: Normalized ATAC-seq data — ATAC_NORM_DATA
text: Unfiltered ATAC sample-level data available via download Google Cloud Storage. example, https://storage.googleapis.com/motrpac-rat-training-6mo-extdata/ATAC_BAT_NORM_DATA.rda file brown adipose tissue (BAT) data. can change name file specify tissues including: HEART, HIPPOC, KIDNEY, LIVER, LUNG, SKMGN (gastrocnemius skeletal muscle), WATSC (subcutaneous white adipose tissue). can also use MotrpacRatTraining6mo::load_sample_data() MotrpacRatTraining6mo::get_rdata_from_url() download raw normalized sample-level data ATAC METHYL. details files see readme repository https://github.com/MoTrPAC/MotrpacRatTraining6mo/blob/main/README.md. Data processed ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline (v1.7.0). Samples single sex training time point, e.g., males trained 2 weeks, analyzed together biological replicates single workflow. Briefly, adapters trimmed cutadapt v2.5 (Martin, 2011) aligned release 96 Ensembl Rattus norvegicus (rn6) genome (Dobin et al., 2013) Bowtie 2 v2.3.4.3 (Langmead Salzberg, 2012). Duplicate reads reads mapping mitochondrial chromosome removed. Signal files peak calls generated using MACS2 v2.2.4 (Gaspar, 2018), reads sample pooled reads biological replicates. Pooled peaks compared peaks called replicate individually using Irreproducibility Discovery Rate (Li et al., 2011) thresholded generate optimal set peaks. cloud implementation ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline source code post-processing steps available https://github.com/MoTrPAC/motrpac-atac-seq-pipeline. Optimal peaks (overlap.optimal_peak.narrowPeak.bed.gz) workflows concatenated, trimmed 200 base pairs around summit, sorted merged bedtools v2.29.0 (Quinlan Hall, 2010) generate master peak list. peak list intersected filtered alignments sample using bedtools coverage options -nonamecheck -counts generate peak sample matrix raw counts. remaining steps applied separately raw counts tissue. Peaks non-autosomal chromosomes removed, well peaks least 10 read counts four samples. Filtered raw counts quantile-normalized limma-voom (Law et al., 2014). subset normalized data corresponding training-regulated features 5% IHW FDR, see ATAC_NORM_DATA_05FDR.

title: Normalized ATAC-seq data for training-regulated features — ATAC_NORM_DATA_05FDR
text: Data processed ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline (v1.7.0). Samples single sex training time point, e.g., males trained 2 weeks, analyzed together biological replicates single workflow. Briefly, adapters trimmed cutadapt v2.5 (Martin, 2011) aligned release 96 Ensembl Rattus norvegicus (rn6) genome (Dobin et al., 2013) Bowtie 2 v2.3.4.3 (Langmead Salzberg, 2012). Duplicate reads reads mapping mitochondrial chromosome removed. Signal files peak calls generated using MACS2 v2.2.4 (Gaspar, 2018), reads sample pooled reads biological replicates. Pooled peaks compared peaks called replicate individually using Irreproducibility Discovery Rate (Li et al., 2011) thresholded generate optimal set peaks. cloud implementation ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline source code post-processing steps available https://github.com/MoTrPAC/motrpac-atac-seq-pipeline. Optimal peaks (overlap.optimal_peak.narrowPeak.bed.gz) workflows concatenated, trimmed 200 base pairs around summit, sorted merged bedtools v2.29.0 (Quinlan Hall, 2010) generate master peak list. peak list intersected filtered alignments sample using bedtools coverage options -nonamecheck -counts generate peak sample matrix raw counts. remaining steps applied separately raw counts tissue. Peaks non-autosomal chromosomes removed, well peaks least 10 read counts four samples. Filtered raw counts quantile-normalized limma-voom (Law et al., 2014). performing differential analysis, training-regulated features selected 5% IHW FDR. normalized data filtered features provided . full set normalized sample-level data, see ATAC_NORM_DATA ATAC_RAW_COUNTS.

Data processed ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline (v1.7.0). Samples single sex training time point, e.g., males trained 2 weeks, analyzed together biological replicates single workflow. Briefly, adapters trimmed cutadapt v2.5 (Martin, 2011) aligned release 96 Ensembl Rattus norvegicus (rn6) genome (Dobin et al., 2013) Bowtie 2 v2.3.4.3 (Langmead Salzberg, 2012). Duplicate reads reads mapping mitochondrial chromosome removed. Signal files peak calls generated using MACS2 v2.2.4 (Gaspar, 2018), reads sample pooled reads biological replicates. Pooled peaks compared peaks called replicate individually using Irreproducibility Discovery Rate (Li et al., 2011) thresholded generate optimal set peaks. cloud implementation ENCODE ATAC-seq pipeline source code post-processing steps available https://github.com/MoTrPAC/motrpac-atac-seq-pipeline. Optimal peaks (overlap.optimal_peak.narrowPeak.bed.gz) workflows concatenated, trimmed 200 base pairs around summit, sorted merged bedtools v2.29.0 (Quinlan Hall, 2010) generate master peak list. peak list intersected filtered alignments sample using bedtools coverage options -nonamecheck -counts generate peak sample matrix raw counts.

title: Feature-to-gene map — FEATURE_TO_GENE
text: data frame 4044034 rows 9 variables: entrez_gene double, Entrez gene ID feature_ID character, MoTrPAC feature identifier rgd_gene integer, RGD gene ID gene_symbol character, official gene symbol old_gene_symbol character, semicolon-separated list deprecated alias gene symbols ensembl_gene character, Ensembl gene ID relationship_to_gene double, ATAC METHYL features . Distance closest edge feature start end closest gene, whichever closer. value 0 means non-zero overlap feature gene. negative value means feature upstream "geneStart". positive value means feature downstream "geneEnd". Note "geneStart" "geneEnd" strand-agnostic, .e. "geneStart" always less "geneEnd", even gene negative strand ("geneStrand" == 2). custom_annotation character, version ChIPseeker annotations many corrections. Values include: "Distal Intergenic", "Promoter (<=1kb)", "Exon", "Promoter (1-2kb)", "Downstream (<5kb)", "Upstream (<5kb)", "5' UTR", "Intron", "3' UTR", "Overlaps Gene" kegg_id character, KEGG ID METAB features . See MotrpacBicQC::metabolomics_data_dictionary details.

title: Feature-to-gene map — FEATURE_TO_GENE
text: proteomics feature IDs (RefSeq accessions) mapped gene symbols Entrez IDs using NCBI’s "gene2refseq" mapping files (https://ftp.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gene/DATA/gene2refseq.gz, downloaded 2020/12/18). Epigenomics features mapped nearest gene using R function ChIPseeker::annotatePeak() Ensembl gene annotation (Rattus norvegicus release 96). Gene symbols, Entrez IDs, Ensembl IDs, RGD IDs mapped using RGD’s rat gene annotation (https://download.rgd.mcw.edu/data_release/RAT/GENES_RAT.txt, generated 2021/11/12).
code: For fast(er) indexing, convert this object to a [data.table::data.table()] and use  [data.table::setkey()] to set the key to the column you are matching.  This dramatically improves performance.

title: Gene-centric universes — GENE_UNIVERSES
text: performing kind enrichment test accept full set measured features input, specify custom background. example, performing enrichment unordered list differential features, background specify full set features tested differential analysis. object provides gene-centric lists "expressed" features, .e. tested differential analysis, assay tissue combinations. convenience, universes specified four different types gene identifers: Entrez/NCBI IDs ("entrez_gene"), gene symbols ("gene_symbol"), Ensembl IDs ("ensembl_gene"), RGD IDs ("rgd_gene"). object list lists, one list per type gene identifier. List structure gene identifier > assay abbreviation > tissue abbreviation, e.g. GENE_UNIVERSES$entrez_gene$PHOSPHO$HEART unique list Entrez genes associated measured phosphosites heart. Universes ATAC METHYL correspond universe expressed genes, .e. TRNSCRPT, actually full set genes associated features measured epigenetic assays. Regardless gene identifier, features METAB universe lists always KEGG IDs, actually gene identifiers.

title: Graph components — GRAPH_COMPONENTS
text: Nodes named format [week]w_F[state]_M[state], [week] one 1, 2, 4, 8 specify training point, [state] takes value 0 (null), 1 (-regulated), -1 (-regulated). Altogether, name node specifies state feature sex specific time point. example, node 1w_F-1_M-1 specifies features -regulated females (F-1) males (M-1) 1-week training time point (1w).

Extract data panel tissue using IMMUNO_NORM_DATA_NESTED[[dataset]][[tissue]], dataset one "ADIPONECTIN", "SERPIN-E", "rat-mag27plex", "rat-metabolic", "rat-myokine", "rat-pituitary", tissue tissue abbreviation (see TISSUE_ABBREV). Samples (vial labels) rows, analytes columns. Column names, barring first "viallabel" column, correspond feature_IDs. Raw mean fluorescent intensities (MFIs) log2-transformed, measurements corresponding wells less 20 beads removed. remaining measurements panel tissue, samples 50\ features least two missing values single experimental group (e.g., males trained 2 weeks) removed (affected four colon analytes one spleen analyte, rat-mag27plex panel). Remaining missing values imputed k-nearest neighbors (k=5 features). Within panel, tissue, analyte, calculated mean standard deviation removed outlying measurements 4 standard deviations away mean. version data provided object used differential analysis. SERPIN-E ADIPONECTIN originally panel called rat-adipokine. split "panels" panel run two dilutions, one optimal SERPIN-E optimal ADIPONECTIN. Hence, places dataset refers "rat-adipokine" places, like , dataset refers "SERPIN-E" "ADIPONECTIN", among others.

title: RRBS raw counts — METHYL_RAW_COUNTS
text: Unfiltered METHYL sample-level data available via download Google Cloud Storage. example, https://storage.googleapis.com/motrpac-rat-training-6mo-extdata/METHYL_BAT_RAW_COUNTS.rda file brown adipose tissue (BAT) data. can change name file specify tissues including: HEART, HIPPOC, KIDNEY, LIVER, LUNG, SKMGN (gastrocnemius skeletal muscle), WATSC (subcutaneous white adipose tissue). can also use MotrpacRatTraining6mo::load_sample_data() MotrpacRatTraining6mo::get_rdata_from_url() download raw normalized sample-level data ATAC METHYL. details files see readme repository https://github.com/MoTrPAC/MotrpacRatTraining6mo/blob/main/README.md. Reads demultiplexed bcl2fastq (version 2.20) using options --use-bases-mask Y*,I8Y*,*,Y* --mask-short-adapter-reads 0 --minimum-trimmed-read-length 0 (Illumina, San Diego, CA, USA), UMIs index FASTQ files attached read FASTQ files. regular 5' 3' adapters trimmed TrimGalore (v1.18), diversity adapter 0 3 bases RDD (R=G D=, G, T) added YGG (Y=C T depending methylation) YGG MspI cut signature trimmed NuGEN script "trimRRBSdiversityAdaptCustomers.py" (https://github.com/nugentechnologies/NuMetRRBS). FastQC (v0.11.8) used generate pre-alignment QC metrics3. Bismark (v0.20.0) used index align reads release 96 Ensembl Rattus norvegicus (rn6) genome gene annotation. lambda genome spiked sample determine bisulfite conversion efficiency, lambda genome (GenBank: J02459.1) also indexed. Default parameters used Bismark’s bismark_genome_preparation alignment step. Bismark output BAM files first formatted using custom script; Bismark’s deduplicate_bismark -p --barcode used remove PCR duplicates bam files; Bismark’s bismark_methylation_extractor    --comprehensive --bedgraph used quantify methylated unmethylated coverages CpG sites. Bowtie 2 (v2.3.4.3) used index align reads globin, rRNA, phix sequences order quantify percent reads mapped contaminants spike-ins5. SAMtools (v1.3.1) used compute mapping percentages different chromosomes6. UMIs used accurately quantify PCR duplicates NuGEN’s "nodup.py" script (https://github.com/tecangenomics/nudup). QC metrics every stage quantification pipeline compiled, part multiQC (v1.6)7. openWDL-based implementation RRBS pipeline Google Cloud Platform available GitHub (https://github.com/MoTrPAC/motrpac-rrbs-pipeline).

title: Rat-to-human gene ortholog map — RAT_TO_HUMAN_GENE
text: map compiled several external sources. GENCODE metadata annotation files used map human Ensembl transcript IDs, Entrez IDs, GENCODE IDs, Ensembl gene IDs (Frankish et al., 2021). RGD files used map human rat gene symbols well various rat gene identifiers (Smith et al., 2020).
code: There is one row per unique combination of \code{RAT_SYMBOL}, \code{RAT_GENE_RGD_ID}, \code{RAT_NCBI_GENE_ID}, \code{RAT_ENSEMBL_ID}, \code{RAT_UNIPROT_ID}, \code{HUMAN_ORTHOLOG_SYMBOL}, \code{HUMAN_ORTHOLOG_RGD}, \code{HUMAN_ORTHOLOG_NCBI_GENE_ID}, and \code{HUMAN_ORTHOLOG_ENSEMBL_ID},  so some genes correspond to multiple rows in the table. For example, there are 24 rows corresponding to \code{RAT_SYMBOL == "Tnf"}  because 3 \code{RAT_ENSEMBL_ID}s correspond to Tnf, and 8 \code{HUMAN_ORTHOLOG_ENSEMBL_ID}s correspond to TNF.
